segments.text: O'Reed was a white man, a minister, I think, of the Unitarian Church, and he was beaten over the head by some redneck, and very seriously injured.
Well, instead of going to the local
medical maternity, and he probably could have been saved now, whether he would have had all his faculties or not, I don't know.
But they drove him to Birmingham without any medical attention.
He was dead.
Brain dead.
No, he was a white man.
But he was there with the blacks on the march.
And that was one tragic
situation that might have been avoided in part.
I don't know whether he could have been saved or not, but the people were there willing to work with the blacks.
They were white doctors.
This cousin of mine was one of them.
He was a thoracic surgeon.
He was standing by, hoping that there could be some use.
And then the other person on the march, Violet Louza, I think she was a woman from Detroit, a white woman too.
It's funny that the two who were killed were white.
And she was shot, and I think she was killed.
because she was sitting by some sort of away thing with some blacks, and a white woman with blacks.
This is an unpardonable sin, and this other red man.
But there were things that, I don't know, it seems as if a great deal of what happened was for the purpose

confrontation uh for instance martin luther king and i admire martin luther king a great deal i disagree with a lot of his methods of that time but you see what he was doing and i and i saw this and understood this was affirming non-violence but confronting
in order to incite violence, you see, against the innocents.
And, of course, by that means, you get a great deal of support.
This was Gandhi's technique, and this has been the classic technique through the years.
And he was a master at it.
But, for instance, he would say, if Congress or the President doesn't do such and such things, there's going to be violence in the streets.
Well, partly as a result of his statements, there would be violence in Israel.
And I think the riots and so forth took place when he was assassinating an outcry in this same block.
But he knew what he was doing.
What you saw wasn't always what was there.
And this was the thing about Martin Luther King, that I had some reservations.
As I say, I admired a great many things.
I knew him.
I've been in meetings with him and spoken to him on a number of occasions.
And he became the great symbol.
This was the important thing.
He became the great symbol to the black people.
And maybe on the basis of what was achieved, this was the way it had to be done.
I mean, of course, he was an educated person.
He had great intelligence and so forth.
And he stayed with the Black Idiot.
He never left it in his manner of speaking and so forth.
Though he could very well have done it if he chose to.
He chose to remain a part of that community and to
Personally, to me, I think he really saw assassination, in a sense.
So he could become a great symbol.
Like that.
Or like Kraus.
This was his conscious purpose.
He saw his role in history.
And he certainly has had a tremendous role in history.
And a very constructive and positive role.
But it was on the basis of inciting violence against himself as well.
And while I was in the midst of all this, I couldn't help it.
I don't know, maybe this is why it happened.
And specifically, as a result, in the
Civil rights actions of, let's see, the 65, the 66, and Johnson's administration, Martin Luther King, and those who worked in this vein made that possible.
For instance, the letter from the Birmingham jail, and the riots in Birmingham,
And then, of course, when he was assassinated, the senseless riots took place everywhere in Washington and other places.
But I don't know what the final answer to something like this is.
This is history, and this is the way things have been accomplished.
But you see, we're getting the reaction to this politically, because

The people in the South and otherwise, like Reagan, who, of course Reagan considers himself not to be a racist in any sense, the practical result of a great many of his policies is to reverse the civil rights and the human rights of the nation.
We are paying the price now, I think, of some of the excesses of that time, even if it's simply to make oneself an object of ours, of those who are proud of ours.
As goodness knows, we still have plenty of land in this country with the freedom to bear arms
about some of the other traditionalist traditions we have in this country in terms of violence.
If King and that vein had not come in, how would you see the state of the South at the present time?
I think probably there would have been less legislative progress and probably more personal progress.
There would be fewer statutes on the books that have been pretty largely reversed.
And there may have been more progress in terms of human relationships in the Senate.
You think that that
by putting in that lava that polarized.
In some sense it did.
I think it was necessary in any event.
But history goes in cycles, and we seem to have been pushed back to the other side of the cycle, setting the progress of the 60s.
Well, starting in the fifties was pretty important, so they moved on through the sixties and into the seventies.
I became pretty disillusioned with a lot of, well, I guess you would say with the radical sheep that came over in the late sixties and the seventies.
Of course, Vietnam was
a lot of this, and Martin Luther King moved on to Vietnam in question.
I couldn't go with a lot of this, of course, like everybody else.
I wish we had never gotten it brought in such a situation, and something had to be done on a confrontational level.

to halt this finally with halted but boy we sure left a residue of bitterness civil rights revolution things that happened in the Vietnam period we are a polarized society even in the church today that polarization
on the basis of ideology.
It's so overwhelming.
You can't get around it to be concerned about humanitarian things and the churches.
Most of my writing in this book is dealing with this issue.
and how the church actually functions in terms of Christian ethics and social action, and so forth.
And I've taken my cue from Bonhoeffer's statement.
The first task of Christian ethics is to invalidate the knowledge of good and evil.
To invalidate the knowledge of good and evil.
Of course, what he was talking about
tendency of the people in the churches to prescribe ethically.
And this is what has happened with the fundamentalists today and their borrowed majority and so forth.
But this is exactly what the liberals were doing in the last generation in prescribing morality for everybody else.
It's a form of pharisaism.
whether it's from a conservative or a liberal stance.
But I think the Christian Church can find a way of dealing with social issues without this kind of ethical restriction.
But at any rate, this is a question I want to explore for all of you.
It's been fascinating to me because I've been on two sides of a lot of different issues.
Of course, a lot.
We think in stereotypes today.
This whole business of literally stereotyping is a stereotype.
But you're automatically lumped with certain people.
which I've seen so much of Texas A&M lately, despite the fact that they've been putting up with the intersection.
So again, students, one of our, well, it appears that the administration has been working in like that.
One of the vice presidents in our student body was put on probationary suspension because he was,
had voted in the Student Senate for the approval of this organization on the campus.
And he had had like 20 parking tickets.
And he had probationary suspension because of his tickets.
So he made himself vulnerable there, didn't he?
Well, he had paid the tickets, though.
Anyway, he took it to court.
To the federal court, the same judge that had put in an injunction or something against the University of Florida's action against the school.
And eventually they sent him out of court, and I guess his father is on the back of it.
His tenure is kind of outspoken out there.
It's an interesting battle down there, I think.
at A&M of all places to fight over that issue with its masculine image of the core and so forth.
They won't let the gals play in the band.
Well, everything around the campus, like even there's a statue in some of our student meetings of a man and a woman at Kennedy because it's preparing for the future.
The man is just
a massive size less than the women, and it's so fatiguing.
That's the traditional A&M image of men and women, huh?
Yeah.
The statue's still there, so this is... Well, we have a lot of traditions to live down, and we're making some that all have to be lived down to, I guess.
Do you see, um, have you been following South African poems lately, too?
Do you see any similarities?
In fact, it's a reminder, so often, of the way things were in our own Southland.
But of course, it's magnified many times now, because, um,
the opportunities have been only for the blacks.

There's never been a question before about, well, they've had to keep the black in his place, because the numbers are so overwhelming, and yet they had to have the blacks to do the work and bring them into the cities and so forth, and they had these separate
There was a very close relationship.
Segregation began at
only at certain levels.
Going to school, or choosing a wife, or dating, and that kind of thing.
And then there were two distinct groups.
But as far as the personal aspects, all the blacks were primarily serving positions.
Still, they had a role.
acceptable, or most of them seem to accept it, but of course that kind of situation can't be maintained.
But there is real segregation, and I'll tell you that somehow.
I just don't see any solution, short of revolution.
When revolution comes, there's no answer.
I'm not optimistic about what could happen.
With the liberalization of the policies of the whites, maybe that could stave it off for a while.
But eventually, it's on its own.
Just as it was in the 18th century and in other places.
in a black state home.
Which is a terrible thing to happen.
That's a mystery.
What happened to your father after that time?
What does he end up doing?
Well, he
in private farms.
Actually, it's a lot of story to it, apart from that particular issue.
But during the Depression, the bank failures and so forth, we had a pretty rugged time.
We lost everything we had.
When I was young, we were pretty affluent.
By the time I got to high school and off to college, I was on my own.
And my dad eventually came back, and so today he was a classic case, and it involved blacks again.
He had been so identified with the black community, both in Little Rock and El Dorado,
There were no black lawyers in those days, at least not in Arkansas.
But this was a rather interesting case, and this one case that provided some financial security for his own name, for his and others' own name.
The suit was lost in the lower court.
It had to do with the inheritance
of a slave, or at least a freed slave, who owned some property and oil was discovered on that property.
And the question, the legal question, was who were the valid heirs of this Edward?
And there were about three sets of heirs.
who were claiming that there was a legitimate marriage, a marriage that was on file.
This was one group of children.
And then there was another earlier marriage, and my father was representing these heirs.
And what he was able to do, from documents and otherwise, was to demonstrate that it was a valid marriage in slave terms.
They had jumped the boom.
And he argued this.
He got into it after it was lost to the court, but they won it through the Supreme Court, the Arkansas Supreme Court.
He wrote a nine-page brief and zeroed in on one point as well.
This he always impressed, as far as legal matters are concerned.
Don't go all over the waterfront.
Find your valid point and stick with it, and let all the rest slough off.
But in these other briefs of hundreds of pages, he wrote a nine-page brief on one
for this group of heirs, and he got a look out of this to find some security for his old age.
And I still have on file that brief, which was sort of a classic, I think, that it convinced the Arkansas Supreme Court.
But that issued it.
later on, he didn't get into politics.
He was influential in backing others.
For instance, you know, I mentioned this Tom McRae, who was president of the Rockefeller Foundation, my nephew.
Tom is about 6'7", a great big tall gang of Arkansas guy.
He's a lawyer, too.
But the way Tom McRae came into being, there was an old congressman who had retired after 25 years in Southwestern District of Arkansas.
And my dad and two or three others in the little office, this was in the early 20s, were looking for somebody who could be honest running for governor.
And if they could find the right man, they would support him, they would raise funds for him.
But Arkansas politics had gotten rid of the sands of corruption and everything else.
And so they zeroed in on this Congressman Gray, who had retired from Congress.
And I guess he was in his sixties at that time.
He wanted them to settle down and live in Prescott, Arkansas.
So, Dad and another man went down to talk to Congress.
They hadn't known him, they were just knowing about reputation.
They asked him to run for governor and support him.
At first, they were confused.
They were an old gentleman who wanted to retire.
But finally,
When all the evidence of the corruption came in, it was like, oh, they went back again.
Well, he won.
He ran.
He won.
He served two terms.
And that's supposed to be a sort of golden age of Arkansas politics, because when McRae was governor.
Well, close friendship developed with the families, and my grandmother, who was living with us in town, and old Mrs. McRae became great friends.
I remember that, oh, when I was a child, I must have been a good boy or something, because
My grandmother, on a couple of occasions, took me to call the governor's wife, took me with her.
I guess I just sat there as a good boy.
But I remember the governor's limousine coming around, picking up my grandmother, and going to visit Mrs. McRae.
And that kind of thing.
Well, when my grandmother was dying, we lived in Alreda at that time, the oldest grave.
and she was driven by a grandson of hers, Carlton.
And at that time, my older sister was walking in the camp or something like that.
She didn't meet him, but years later, Carlton came down the road.
He was a chemist working in the laboratory, flying oil.
And they were saying, well, when you go down there, they'd be sure to look up that Rogers girl.
And he kind of put them out there.
He said he would.
It took him a year to get around it.
But then things moved pretty fast.
So my oldest sister married the old governor's grandson.
And their oldest son is Thomas C. McRae IV.
And that's the time when
But that was the kind of involvement in politics that he needed to learn much, and he was too identified as a nigger logger.
This was a phrase I heard used too many times.
I don't know.
He accepted it and became kind of a badge of honor.
But the idea behind it was that, I mean, the deprecating idea was that any lawyer who was low enough to defend niggers, you know what I'm saying, was something a little wrong.
That's the way things were.
Well, Faubus was sort of a throwback.
Faubus, when he was coming along, was a very different person.
what he was later.
You know, he went to that, what was it, the Commonwealth College that was supposed to be a communist institution, you know?
Not that he was a communist, but a boy from the backwoods who liked boggles.
He'd go to college where he could, ambitious, backwoods boy.
But all of us tried a power play.
I don't know if he was really ever sympathetic to the segregationists, but he wouldn't do that.
And Asim Kaur,
in those areas, and refused to send in the troops to protect those kids in Central High.
No one called us and took advantage of it.
There's a background on it.
He calls it the power of the country.
So I'll make you later to see what we do.
because it was a lot of trouble that was caused.
Well, others were vindicated and opposed.
It's real interesting.
The Arkansas political scene now is very different.
one of the things in the family that my nephew has often been expected to do.
His mother, my sister, and others in the family were expected that he would want to go, because he still hasn't met the man that he still remembered at the start.
And Tom has never really, he has,
worked with somebody.
He was, incidentally, he was the governor's administrative assistant.
Bumpers.
For a long time, of course, Bumpers was in the Senate.
And he got a lot of solid experience in that situation.
But we never really desire to run for governor.
Before he dies, maybe.
Maybe he'll be persuaded like his great-grandfather.
I think he's gotten a lot of publicity out of it.
What the Rockefeller Foundation has done is to identify
causes that need to be pursued.
And then to pour money into studies, to get professionals who can really deal with those things.
And every time one of his major studies has come out,
for instance, they did one of the public schools in Arkansas.
Really, this thing in Texas was modeled after, or at least something of the same thing.
And they made some, the foundation report
made some very strong recommendations about public schools in Arkansas, on the caliber of teachers.
One of the things I noticed in the paper recently, they're doing, they're testing teachers, and a lot of the teachers are protesting this.
A lot of the teachers couldn't pass the tests that the students are required to do.
Of course, the unfortunate thing about this is it hits a lot of black people's situations.
There is still an inequality there, an inequality achieved as far as objective tests are concerned.
And this is a real concern, and I think the report
The Rockefeller Foundation put out about it, suggesting making judgments about the black experience and so forth.
There'd be a different kind of test or something.
The way it's come out, they've all been tested the same way.
This is inherently unfair.
and a lot of the teachers.
Of course, right now, the issue is not so much on the black flag issue, but just another concern of the teachers.
That's a strong concern in my school, especially because of that stereotype of the people that are in the education majors being literate at all at our school.
put down as far as, you know, if you're talking about an age group, they might still go to art school.
I'm concerned that those things could be in as far as, you know, education especially.
I don't know.
I guess it just goes down.
You've got the ethnic and being in business or engineering or something.
Well, of course, this is North Texas' tradition.
This is, at one time, North Texas State Teachers College, and our normal school, even before then.
And the large school of education has to fight this, because they're trying to upgrade the standards.
They're not high in the school of education.
This is one of the problems.
They're leaving some of the selectivity.
They're not just a black community, but a white community as well.
Education courses seem to be more passable than content courses.
It creates a problem.
When the students here were getting involved in the news here in the 60s, did they participate in sit-ins and demonstrations and things like that?
Was there a SNCC, Student Nonviolent Learning Community?
I don't think there was a SNCC on this campus, but of course there have been a lot of other places.
But no, there was, I don't know that it ever, the town capitulated pretty fast that first year.
There were a lot of problems.
For instance, blacks who would commute in from Dallas, where would they eat?
And we, at our student center, we had a sort of a lunch place where people could come in and bring their sack lunches.
Most were blacks, but they didn't have anywhere else to go.
And that kind of thing.
Well, that lasted all of the confrontations and things in the community lasted longer than that.
People just hadn't gotten used to that.
The threat and the boycott of the campus theater by some of the students took care of that situation really well.
Because, you know, there was strong sympathy among the white students.
You know, there's those two theaters on the square.
Was one of those originally for blacks?
No, no, no, no.
The blacks had to go up and down.
It was segregated.
That was it.
It wasn't too separate.
No, no.
I think in Bryan there's one.
I guess in Bryan there's an old theater where there's a back door where they went in and bought the tickets.
Yeah, I remember that from childhood.
Yeah.
Of course, theaters wouldn't turn away the black trade, but they'd just paint them with side entrants or back entrants and sit up, I doubt, in some other place.
But those things are no more.
Thank you.
I think I've said enough.
All right.
